div.p: Hi. My name's John Barkanic.
I've been with DeSales University in the ACCESS Program,
Mathematics Department, for over 20 years now.
Probably half the students who come into the math classes are stressed out.
They have math anxiety.
They have not exercised their math skills.
The other half are pretty comfortable with mathematics, either from other courses
that they've had, or because they've done well in school-in other math courses in school,
high school, or they have a feel for mathematics.
For the half that is not comfortable or is stress out,
there are couple of things that are useful.
One is to not overload.
Some people try to take double classes.
My advice is don't try to take a math class coupled with some other course.
There's enough work already in the math course to keep you busy the full eight weeks.
The folks that do double up on classes,
really don't get what they need to get out of the math class.
Even if they pass it successfully, they're not really getting the education
from the course that they should be getting.
That's one aspect of it.The second thing to deal with stress and anxiety is like anything else.
If you don't know something you stress out about it.
Most people who take the test, after the test,
they look at the problem and say, "This is so easy!
I see how to do it and it's so easy.
Why couldn't I see it in the class?"
Well, that awareness of how a problem comes together and why it's obvious now
that you know how to do it comes with practice.
So you have to find a way to make the time to do problems.
All the talk in the world isn't going to make you an expert in mathematics.
Sitting through all the lectures in the world isn't going to make you skilled in mathematics.
Until you take pencil to paper and start solving math problems, you're not going to be able
to take tests and do well on tests.
And that's what this is about-- being able to test well,
understand the material and test well.
You have to put pencil to paper, you have to solve problems, and that takes time.
Just make time to practice.
Find the time to practice the material.
